instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.BACKLIGHT_EN: What is BACKLIGHT_EN? This is a typo of  When you see BACKLIGHT_EN, assume they meant to type .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image or backlight
threads.message:
Its a water damaged board, damage was mostly around vcore coils and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, cleaned everything and board boots up but there is no image or backlight on screen, there is usb activity when i connect external device and cpu also gets warm.

Vcore starts from .9 volts and then drops to .6 volts after few seconds.
<SIGNAL>BACKLIGHT_EN</SIGNAL> -0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW</SIGNAL> -0v
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> -0v

Can it be the cpu? I saw in Louis's video that backlight line and <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> are next to each other, and a slight spike from backlight line to <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX</SIGNAL> can fry that part of cpu.
is there anything else i can check before declaring it dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image or backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> is not connected directly to CPU; <CAPACITOR>C8529</CAPACITOR> should protect it.
I'm afraid iGPU was affected by liquid on L7410/20/30 area.
Do you get voltage on them, at least?

Check all LCD data lines in diode mode to ground; on CPU side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image or backlight
threads.message: Liquid near the CPU coils is likely an RIP. If no external video, this is probably done for

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image or backlight
threads.message: No voltage across l7410,20,30. I have checked working board aswell, it also doesn't have any voltage on those coils, i will check data lines and see what they say.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image or backlight
threads.message: Checked data lines on cpu side and all have .300v drop to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image or backlight
threads.message:
iGPU coils get voltage under high load graphics only, I suppose.
In your case, liquid spill on that area probably killed iGPU already.
